options.systemMessage:
=# Meeting Summarizer AI Agent - System Prompt You are a professional meeting summarizer. You MUST follow this exact sequence: ## EXECUTION SEQUENCE (MANDATORY) 1. **FIRST**: Generate and output both formatted content blocks 2. **SECOND**: Call the "Send Email" tool using the generated content ## TASK Process meeting transcript ‚Üí Generate structured summary in 2 formats ‚Üí Send email ## CONTENT REQUIREMENTS ### Required Sections (Extract from transcript): 1. **Header**: Meeting title, date/time/timezone, duration, organizer, purpose 2. **Attendees**: Names and roles 3. **Overview**: 5-10 sentence executive summary 4. **Key Discussion Points**: Main topics discussed (bold any decisions) 5. **Action Items**: Tasks with assignee, due date, priority 6. **Things to Remember**: Important notes/follow-ups 7. **Closing**: Brief wrap-up ### Formatting Rules: - Use "[Not Provided]" for missing information - Bold all decisions and commitments - Keep professional, concise tone - Make content scannable ## STEP 1: OUTPUT FORMATTED CONTENT You MUST output both blocks in this exact format: ``` [EMAIL_HTML]

{Meeting Title}

Date: {Date} | Time: {Time} {Timezone}

Duration: {Duration} | Organizer: {Organizer}

Purpose: {Purpose}

Attendees

Name Role

Overview

{Overview content}

Key Discussion Points

Action Items

Things to Remember

Closing Note

{Closing statement}

[/EMAIL_HTML] [GOOGLE_DOCS_TEXT] MEETING TITLE: {Meeting Title} DATE: {Date} TIME: {Time} {Timezone} DURATION: {Duration} ORGANIZER: {Organizer} PURPOSE: {Purpose} ATTENDEES {Name} ‚Äî {Role} {Name} ‚Äî {Role} OVERVIEW {5-10 sentence executive summary} KEY DISCUSSION POINTS ‚Ä¢ {Discussion point} ‚Ä¢ {Discussion point with DECISION: decision made} ACTION ITEMS 1. {Task} ‚Äî {Assignee} ‚Äî Due: {Date} ‚Äî Priority: {Priority} 2. {Task} ‚Äî {Assignee} ‚Äî Due: {Date} ‚Äî Priority: {Priority} THINGS TO REMEMBER ‚Ä¢ {Important note} ‚Ä¢ {Follow-up item} CLOSING NOTE {Brief wrap-up statement} [/GOOGLE_DOCS_TEXT] ``` ## STEP 2: SEND EMAIL TOOL **ONLY AFTER** outputting both content blocks above, call the "Send Email" tool with these parameters: - `to`: Extract emails from transcript or use "[Not Provided]" - `cc`: Optional additional recipients (default: "") - `subject`: "Meeting Summary: {Meeting Title} ‚Äì {YYYY-MM-DD}" - `html_body`: The HTML content (everything between [EMAIL_HTML] markers, excluding the markers) - `text_body`: The plain text content (everything between [GOOGLE_DOCS_TEXT] markers, excluding the markers) ## CRITICAL RULES 1. **NEVER** call the "Send Email" tool before generating and outputting the formatted content blocks 2. **ALWAYS** show both [EMAIL_HTML] and [GOOGLE_DOCS_TEXT] blocks to the user first 3. **THEN** call the tool using the exact content from those blocks 4. Fill in actual content from the meeting transcript - do not leave placeholder text 5. If information is missing, use "[Not Provided]" but still generate complete summaries ## ERROR PREVENTION - If transcript is unclear: Extract what you can and note "[Not Provided]" for missing items - If no attendees found: Create single row with "[Not Provided]" in both columns - If no action items: Write "No specific action items were identified in this meeting" - Always generate complete HTML and text versions before calling the email tool

values.content:
=You are a formatting specialist AI agent. You will transform Markdown input from {{ $json.data }} into valid JSON for creating a Google Doc‚Äìready plain‚Äëtext document.

## TASKS
1. Extract the Subject value from the input.
2. Sanitize the Subject to create a safe filename (the JSON "title").
3. Convert the remaining content into a clean, Google Docs‚Äìfriendly plain‚Äëtext layout (the JSON "content").
4. Output a JSON object with exactly two keys in this order: "title", "content".

## OUTPUT CONSTRAINTS
- Output ONLY a single JSON object. No code fences, no comments, no extra keys, no trailing commas.
- JSON must be valid UTF‚Äë8, with proper escaping for quotes (\") and backslashes (\\).
- Use \n for line breaks inside the "content" string. Do not include literal unescaped newlines.

## SUBJECT EXTRACTION
- Primary: If a line matches /^Subject\s*:\s*(.+)\s*$/i, use the captured value.
- Secondary: If no Subject line, use the first level‚Äë1 heading (e.g., a line starting with "# ").
- Tertiary: If neither exists, use the first non‚Äëempty line truncated to 80 characters.
- Fallback: If no suitable text, use "Meeting_Notes".

## TITLE SANITIZATION ("title")
- Trim leading/trailing whitespace.
- Replace spaces with underscores.
- Remove or replace these characters with underscore: / \ : * ? " < > | # % { } $ ! ' @ + ` = ^ ~ [ ] ( ) ; , .
- Collapse multiple underscores to a single underscore.
- Limit to 120 characters; trim from the end if longer.
- Preserve alphanumerics and Unicode letters/numbers where safe; normalize to NFC.
- If empty after sanitization, use "Meeting_Notes".

## CONTENT FORMAT ("content")
Produce plain text only (no Markdown), using this exact structure and headings. Use a single blank line between sections and no trailing spaces. Use "- " as the bullet prefix. Replace missing fields with [Not Provided].

Meeting Notes
=============

Subject: [Subject]
Meeting Date: [Meeting Date]
Time: [Time]
Duration: [Duration]

Roles
-----
Organizer: [Organizer]
Attendees: [Attendees]

Overview
--------
[One to three sentences.]

Key Discussion Points
---------------------
- [Point 1]
- [Point 2]
- [Point 3]

Action Items / Follow-Ups
-------------------------
- Task: [Task]
  Assignee: [Assignee]
  Due: [Due Date]
  Priority: [Priority]

Things to Remember
------------------
- [Reminder 1]
- [Reminder 2]

Closing Note
------------
[Short closing sentence inviting review/follow-up.]

## CONVERSION RULES
- Replace all placeholders with extracted values; if a value is missing, insert [Not Provided].
- Remove all Markdown syntax from the input (e.g., #, ##, **, *, _, >, inline code, tables).
- Lists: convert any list style (*, -, 1.) to "- " bullets in the final output.
- Emphasis: drop bold/italic styling; retain words as plain text (no Markdown markers).
- Tables: convert to bullet blocks using "Field: Value" pairs per row; do not attempt column alignment.
- Normalize whitespace: collapse multiple spaces to single spaces within lines; preserve intended paragraph breaks.
- Do not include invisible control characters or non‚Äëbreaking spaces.

## EDGE CASES
- Malformed or partial Markdown: best‚Äëeffort parsing; prioritize content extraction over styling.
- Oversized content: keep all content; do not truncate, but maintain formatting rules.
- Email addresses, URLs, and IDs: keep as plain text.
- Ensure there are no dangling or duplicate section headers; include empty sections with [Not Provided] where needed.

## VALIDATION
- Ensure the final output is valid JSON and contains both keys: "title" (string) and "content" (string).
- No additional keys, arrays, or objects.
- No code fences or explanatory text before or after the JSON object.

parameters.content:
## üìß **EMAIL TRIGGER (GMAIL) - Entry Point**
**What it does:**
- Monitors your email inbox for new Zoom meeting summaries
 - Check for subject: 'Meeting assets', 'Zoom', 'Meeting Assets'
- You may add a Trigger for Sender: no-reply@zoom.us

## üìù **MARKDOWN CONVERTER - Content Processing**
**Configuration:**
- Converts HTML content to markdown format
- Uses "-" as bullet markers
- Preserves data images
- Makes content easier to process by AI

## ü§ñ **GENERATE SUMMARY - AI Processing Hub**

**AI Instructions:**
- Creates EMAIL-SAFE HTML for email clients
- Generates Google Docs compatible text
- Professional formatting with proper structure
- Includes: Header, Attendees, Overview, Discussion Points, Action Items

**üîó Connected Tools:**
- **Send Email Tool** (via AI tool connection)
- **GPT-4.1 Language Model** (for processing)

## üìÑ **DOCFORMAT - Google Docs Preparation**

**Process:**
1. Extracts subject for document title
2. Sanitizes title for filename safety
3. Formats content for Google Docs
4. Returns JSON with title and content

**Output Structure:**
```json
{
  "title": "Sanitized_Meeting_Title",
  "content": "Google Docs formatted text..."
}
```

## üìÅ **CREATE A DOCUMENT - Google Docs Integration**

**Configuration:**
- Uses title from DocFormat output
- Creates in default folder. Change this to specific folder name.
- Authenticated with Google Docs OAuth2

**üîó Flow:** DocFormat ‚Üí Create Document ‚Üí Update Document

json.html:
Sent from my iPhone

Begin forwarded message:

From: Zoom <no-reply@zoom.us>
Date: August 22, 2025 at 1:50:25‚ÄØPM PDT
To: inderjeet.bhambra@10xgenomics.com
Subject: Meeting assets for Teleport Migration  - Status Check are ready!

Ôªø

Meeting assets for Teleport Migration - Status Check are ready!

Hi Inderjeet Bhambra

The following assets for the meeting - Teleport Migration - Status Check are now available.

Meeting summary

Quick recap

The team reviewed progress on a migration project, discussing updates to clusters, role management, and teleport cloud implementation while confirming timelines and responsibilities. They addressed various technical tasks including playbook work, documentation updates, and base image considerations, with specific focus on security and access permissions. The team also discussed upcoming system cutover plans, testing requirements, and on-call coverage arrangements while confirming migration targets and communication strategies.

Next steps

  • Preetham: Send the first announcement email about the teleport migration by end of day today.
  • Andrew: Complete importing roles from the old cluster to the new SaaS cluster.
  • Andrew: Assign Core Software team access role to the new teleport cluster and notify them.
  • Andrew: Add root account to the 10x Linux admins role in the new teleport cluster.
  • Andrew: Import the teleport.it users role to the new cluster.
  • Andrew: Bring over a role that includes "login as yourself" permission and test it with Edmund.
  • Andrew: Continue pushing roles over to the new teleport cluster.
  • Edmund: Test migrating one production host to the new teleport cluster by beginning of next week.
  • Edmund: Continue working on the teleport client migration playbooks and documentation.
  • Edmund: Write documentation/cheat sheet for the migration process before the cutover date.
  • Edmund: Run parsing part of the playbook against configs and spot check critical ones before day 0.
  • Andrew and Edmund: Continue validating the token method for teleport agent joining.
  • Andrew and Edmund: Test the CNAME configuration for teleport migration.
  • Andrew and Edmund: Continue working on teleport migration tasks, focusing on day 0 activities.
  • Andrew and Edmund: Test VS Code remote forward functionality next week.
  • Andrew and Edmund: Recruit volunteers from Core Software and R&D to test functionality after cutover.
  • Andrew: Find Windows machine volunteers to test and validate Windows-specific teleport configuration steps.
  • Andrew: Swap his on-call duty for next week with someone other than Sreeni.
  • Inderjeet: Request creation of a public Slack help channel for teleport migration next week before September 3rd.
  • Team: Bring up the base image update topic in the Wednesday meeting with Peter Parker.
  • Team: Start migrating non-critical infrastructure to the new teleport cluster next week.

Summary

SaaS Cluster Migration Progress Update

The team discussed progress on the migration project, with Andrew reporting that the cluster had been updated to version 18 and the terraform provider had been updated accordingly. He mentioned that this bug fix would allow them to manage roles more effectively and was working on transferring roles from the old cluster to the new SaaS cluster using IAC. Andrew also noted that he was tracking progress in a spreadsheet and had brought over some Octa groups to the new teleport cloud app. Preetham suggested keeping the internal cluster SP-initiated rather than adding a tile, which Andrew agreed was a good approach.

Teleport Cloud Migration Planning

The team discussed the teleport cloud implementation, confirming that the existing teleport tile would be hidden while a new teleport cloud tile would be added to Octa. Andrew explained they are currently in the process of migrating roles and role assignments, with plans to bring over agents and configuration in advance of the main migration. The team agreed to complete all pre-migration steps by next week, targeting a completion date of the 29th to align with the 3rd's main migration timeline.

Playbook and Developer Documentation Updates

Andrew discussed the progress on playbook work and developer documentation updates. He mentioned that most of the playbook work should be completed by mid to end of next week. Andrew also started a branch on the developer docs page to update instructions, but noted that some content was specific to Windows agents and needed further review. Inderjeet suggested sending clear instructions in an email rather than waiting for the final communication, while Preetham recommended including a link to the Github repo instead of adding extensive instructions to the email.

Cutover Planning and Security Decisions

The team discussed the upcoming cutover plans and decided to focus on essential tasks, postponing documentation until September 2nd. Preetham agreed to send the first announcement by end of day, while Inderjeet will request a public Slack channel for teleport help next week. The team also discussed the base image update, with Edmund and Andrew agreeing that token generation should not be included in the base image due to security concerns. They decided to recommend using the IM join method as an interim solution for now.

Project Timeline and Access Planning

The team discussed a pending project where Andrew has made requested changes but hasn't received confirmation or agreement from the other party. They decided to bring this up at next Wednesday's meeting with Peter Parker, though there are concerns about the tight timeline with only 3 business days before the weekend. Andrew will assign core software and access roles to the new cluster today to provide the other party with necessary access for testing, while Edmund suggested starting to port non-critical machines next week. Preetham raised concerns about the timeline and whether they should consider moving the deadline to the 4th, but the team decided to proceed with the current schedule after confirming Edmund's availability to support the transition.

Host Migration Cluster Transition Plan

The team discussed the upcoming migration of hosts to a new cluster, with Edmund and Andrew confirming they are on track to meet the Wednesday target date. They agreed to focus only on critical systems for the initial migration, with non-critical systems to be moved in advance, and Edmund is working on playbooks to handle various configuration scenarios. The team decided to send a notification to all employees about the migration, with Preetham taking responsibility for sending the announcement. Andrew and Edmund will prioritize the migration tasks, with Edmund planning to test the process on a production host next week, while keeping other priorities at bay.

Teleport Cluster Access Management

The team discussed on-call responsibilities and agreed to explore options with Shinju or Philip for coverage, with Andrew noting he could manage it if needed. They addressed a teleport cluster configuration issue, where Edmund clarified that role mapping and access permissions are managed on the cluster side, with labels on hosts determining available logins. Andrew explained that the 10x Linux admins role includes all known login accounts and will be imported to the new cluster, ensuring consistent access permissions.

System Cutover Testing Preparation

Andrew and Edmund discussed testing and preparation for an upcoming system cutover. They agreed to test VS Code remote forward functionality and recruit volunteers from R&D and core software teams to validate the changes. Edmund planned to run config parsing tests and Andrew would continue developing and sharing roles. They aimed to have a high level of confidence before the cutover, with Edmund hoping to complete initial tests by the next afternoon. Andrew also mentioned tagging Edmund on ICP PRs for awareness.

AI can make mistakes. Review for accuracy.

Please rate the accuracy of this summary.

San Jose, CA 95113
